div.p: Greetings. I do not doubt, most learned man, that I am accused by you not only of negligence and laziness, because I have not sent you any letters for a long time, but also of ingratitude. It would indeed be very serious for me to have incurred such suspicion with you, if I were not very well aware of my own innocence and if there were not reasons at hand that could immediately clear me of this unfavorable opinion. These reasons are: for a long time I have suffered from eye pain and, exhausted by severe inflammation, I have not been able to write. To this was also added the fact that no messenger presented himself to whom I could entrust my letters. Because of these things, you ought to consider it kindly, and if these do not satisfy, you should use that [Greek] which you always use in the errors of friends. I ask you again and again to do this, in the manner of the accused. If I were not pressed by the constraints of time, I would have written to you more extensively; but shortly, as I hope, this will happen, and if anything new occurs, I will write diligently.
Farewell, distinguished no less in holiness of life than in doctrine. In Basel, on the very Nones of June in the Christian year 1557.
To the most venerable lord and teacher, Heinrich Bullinger, endowed with uncommon piety and knowledge of sciences and languages. In ZÃ¼rich.
